question: -- killed everyone off so her son Tiberius could inherit the throne. Just like Nixon. You sure? I'm making soy cutlets.
answer: I'm fine. Already ate.

question: Wait. You've been kissing.
answer: No I haven't.

question: Yes... yes, you have...
answer: No I haven't.

question: Yes you have. I can tell.
answer: You can't tell.

question: Not only can I tell, I know who it is. It's Darryl.
answer: It's unfair that we can't listen to our music!

question: Honey, it's all about drugs and promiscuous sex.
answer: Simon and Garfunkel is poetry!

question: Yes it's poetry. It's the poetry of drugs and promiscuous sex. Look at the picture on the cover...
answer: First it was butter, then sugar and white flour. Bacon. Eggs, bologna, rock and roll, motorcycles.

question: That was an experiment. But I understand -
answer: What else are you going to ban?

question: Honey, you want to rebel against knowledge.
answer: We're like nobody else I know.

question: I'm a teacher. Why can't I teach my own kids? Use me.
answer: Darryl says you use knowledge to keep me down. He says I'm a "yes" person and you're trying to raise us in a "no" environment!

question: Hey!
answer: I think she said "feck."

question: What's the difference?
answer: Well. The letter "u"... Yeah. I had 'em. I shaved 'em off.

question: Put on your seatbelt. I don't want you flying through the windshield.
answer: We got our annuals today --

question: "Received" your annual.
answer: I look so much younger than everyone else.

question: Enjoy it while you can.
answer: Mom. It's time.

question: Can this wait until we get home?
answer: Mom, pull over. Tell him the truth. Tell him how old he is.

question: He knows how old he is.
answer: The other kids make fun of him because of How young he looks. Nobody includes him.

question: You lied to him! You make such a big deal about the truth and you lied!
answer: He never asked.

question: What -- like he's going to ask if he's as old as he thinks he is? Don't you realize, this is going to scar him forever?
answer: Honey... sweetheart... don't be Cleopatra. We have to be his mother and his Dad.

question: ... am I?
answer: I skipped you an extra grade. You're eleven.

question: ELEVEN?
answer: So you skipped fifth grade. There's too much padding In the grades. I taught elementary school. 5th grade - unnecessary. Nothing happens in the 5th grade. All Teachers know it, no one talks about it.

question: E - leven.
answer: And you skipped kindergarten because I taught it to you when you were four.

question: Honey, I know you were expecting puberty. You're just going to have to shine it on for a while.
answer: Who needs a "crowd?" You're unique. You're two years ahead of everybody. Take those extra years and do what you want. Go to Europe for a year! Take a look around, see what you like! Follow your dream! You'll still be the youngest lawyer in the country. Your own great grandfather practiced law until he was 93. Your dad was so proud of you. He knew you were a pronominally accelerated child.

question: What about me?
answer: You're rebellious and ungrateful of my love.

question: Found it!! So you're the one who's been sending me those articles from your school newspaper -
answer: I've been doing some stuff for a local underground paper, too.

question: What are you like the star of your school?
answer: They hate me.

question: You'll meet them all again on their long journey to the middle.
answer: I did?

question: Oh yeah. It's over.
answer: Over?

question: Over. You got here just in time for the death rattle, the last gasp, the last grope.
answer: Well. At least I'm here for that.

question: What do you type on?
answer: Smith-Corona Galaxis Deluxe.

question: You like the new Lou Reed?
answer: The early stuff. The new stuff, he's trying to be Bowie, he should be himself. I'm not a big Lou man.

question: Yeah, but if Bowie's doing Lou, and Lou's Doing Bowie, Lou's still doing Lou.
answer: If you like Lou.

question: Take drugs?
answer: No.

question: Smart kid. I used to do speed and sometimes Nyquil and stay up all night writing and writing, like 25 pages of dribble about, you know, the Guess Who, or Coltrane, just to write, you know, with the music blasting...
answer: Me too. The writing part...

question: Well, alright. It's been nice to meet you. I'll see you around. Keep sending me your stuff.
answer: Okay. See you.

question: I can't stand here all day talking to my many fans. -- so anyway, you're from San Diego and that's good. Because once you go to L.A., you're gonna have friends like crazy but they'll be fake friends, they're gonna try to corrupt you. The publicists! The bands! You got an honest face, they're gonna tell you everything. But you CANNOT make friends with the rock stars.
answer: ... Industry... of... cool...

question: And that's what they want! And it's happening right now. I'm telling you, you're coming along at a very dangerous time for rock and roll. The war is over. They won. 99% of what passes for rock now... SILENCE is much more compelling. It's over. I think you should turn around and go back and be... a lawyer or something... but I can see from your face that you won't. I can pay you thirty-five bucks. Gimme a thousand words on Black Sabbath.
answer: An assignment. Honest... unmerciful...

question: Look at this. An entire generation of Cinderellas and there's no slipper coming.
answer: You can drop me off here.

question: Black. Sabbath. Just remember - you wanted to be Atticus Finch in To Kill a Mockingbird.
answer: All I have to do is listen. That's what Lester Bangs said.

question: I'll be waiting right here at eleven 'o clock sharp. If you get lost, use the family whistle.
answer: Hi. I'm William Miller and I'm here from Creem Magazine to interview the band Black Sabbath.

question: Hi. I'm William Miller and I'm here from Creem Magazine to interview the band Black Sabbath.
answer: Not on the list.

question: Sir, I'm a journalist, and here's a copy of the magazine.
answer: You're not on the list. Go to the top of the ramp with the girls!

question: What-happens-after-I-go-to-the-top-of- the-ramp with-the-gi -
answer: Who are you with?

question: Me? I'm with myself.
answer: No, who are you with? What band?

question: I'm here to interview Black Sabbath. I'm a journalist. I'm not a... you know...
answer: ... you're not a what?

question: Oh... I'm just... not a... you know.
answer: Not a "what"?

question: "Groupies" sleep with rock stars because they want to be near someone famous. We are here because of the music. We are Band Aids.
answer: She used to run a school for Band Aids.

question: We don't have intercourse with these guys. We support the music. We inspire the music. We are here because of the music.
answer: Marc Bolan broke her heart, man. It's famous.

question: It's a long story. I'm retired now. I'm just visiting friends.
answer: She was the one who changed everything. She said "no more sex, no more exploiting our bodies and hearts... "

question: Red Dog!
answer: This is Red Dog, the Allman Brothers Band's number one roadie.

question: How're the guys? ... and it's okay, because rock and roll is a LIFESTYLE... and a way of thinking and it's not about money and "popularity!"
answer: Some money would be nice.

question: - but it's a voice that says here I am... and FUCK YOU if you can't understand me.
answer: And the chicks are great.

question: I found you a pass.
answer: Thanks. I got in with Stillwater. The guitarist, Russel Hammond, he just thoroughly opened up. He is by far the best and most honest interview I've ever done. I've only done two, but you know. He's number one.

question: You're learning. They're much more fun on the way up.
answer: Eighteen.

question: Me too. How old are we really?
answer: Seventeen.

question: Me too.
answer: Actually I'm 16.

question: Me too. Isn't it funny? The truth just sounds Different.
You want to know how old I really am?
answer: No.

question: It's a long story.
answer: Right. Right.

question: You just missed Russell! He says he's at the "Riot House" all week and to call him. He's under the name Harry Houdini. Do you know about the "Riot House?"
answer: I think I've heard of it.

question: He had a message for you! He said, "It's not California without you. We want you around like last summer." Actually he said "ain't." "It ain't California - "
answer: I get the gist.

question: How well do you guys know each other?
answer: Call me if you need a rescue. We live in the same city.

question: I think I live in a different world.
answer: Speaking of the world. I've made a decision. I'm going to live in Morocco for one year. I need a new crowd.

question: Yes.
answer: It's a plan. You've got to call me.

question: Okay.
answer: It's all happening.

question: It's all happening. Hey Darryl.
answer: Hey.

question: Yeah. She and Mom are still sorta... I'd say "not speaking," but I don't know if they ever did.
answer: Your sister. A stewardess. The things your sister and I did inside these four walls...

question: That's okay. I don't want to know. It's my room now.
answer: We flew the friendly skies -

question: Okay -
answer: I don't want to put you in the middle of anything. We don't have to talk about it.

question: No.
answer: You seem cooler.

question: Yeah. I'm thinking about going to Morocco.
answer: Lemme know if you need a little help with your Mom.

question: A little might not be enough.
answer: She still freaks me out.

question: Yeah -
answer: She's famous.

question: Listen -
answer: Go ahead and do what you were doing. I just wanna hang in here for a moment.

question: Cool. Alright.
answer: Okay, man.

question: Okay, man.
answer: I worry about the drunk drivers.

question: Mom. I'm 15. Right?
answer: Yes, you're 15. "And here's that money I owed you."

question: I thought it was pretty good.
answer: Keep the small bills on the outside. And call me if anyone gets drunk.

question: I will call you if anyone anywhere gets drunk.
answer: Good.

question: And don't take drugs.
answer: Ha ha. Very funny. See -- sense of humor. Have fun at the dance. I'm glad you're making friends.

question: Mom?
answer: Yeah -

question: Stay.
answer: Oh... okay.

question: I just worry about people using her. You know? 'Cause she brings out the good side in everybody else, but what do they do for her? Life kills me. Do you have any pot?
answer: Not on me.

question: Do you smoke?
answer: No. But I... I grow it. I grow it.

question: You're funny. You know, if you were only taller, English, rich, a guitar- player and older...
answer: I'd be someone else.

question: How does it end?
answer: What?

question: You know - the story about the girl who dumps the guy who has an ex-ex wife -- the one we don't talk about -- and gets a hundred... okay, five letters from him, and then doesn't even leave a pass in San Diego. Wake up! I'm retired and I never believed you anyway. You're too talented and too good-looking to be trusted and everybody knows it.
answer: You're retired like Frank Sinatra is retired.

question: Damn.
answer: Come to Arizona.

question: Never.
answer: We leave Thursday morning. 9 AM. And pack light this time. Jesus.

question: This is he.
answer: Crazy. William, this is Ben Fong- Torres. I'm the music editor at Rolling Stone Magazine. We've got a copy of your stories from the San Diego Door. This is the same William Miller?

question: Yes it is.
answer: Voice of God, howling dogs, the spirit of rock And roll... this is good solid stuff.

question: Thanks... thanks.
answer: You should be writing for us. Any ideas?

question: How about Stillwater?
answer: Crazy. New album... their third... starting to do something.

question: Sounds good.
answer: We can only pay -- lemme see, three- thousand words -- seven hundred dollars.

question: Yes.
answer: What college --

question: Beware Rolling Stone Magazine. They will change your story, they'll re- write it and turn it into swill. Beware!!
answer: But besides that, what would be wrong with it?

question: You have starry eyes, my friend. Look. Do the story. It's a good break for ya. But remember this --
answer: ... swill merchants...

question: Now. What are you listening to?
answer: I need to talk to Mrs. Deegan, from Journalism.

question: What's involved?
answer: Well. It's a great opportunity. He'll be well-paid, and published nationally -- -- and he'll go on tour with a rock band for four days. No small planes... he travels on a bus.

question: Is it time for me to say something?
answer: Sure.

question: No.
answer: And in anticipation of that response -

question: No.
answer: -- William has prepared --

question: Russell. Do you think we might be able to find some time to talk when we get to Phoenix? I want to interview everyone separately... and I felt we'd start with you and me.
answer: Absolutely.

question: Because I've got a thing in a couple days.
answer: What.

question: It's a... thing where... uhm... you go there to graduate. School.
answer: I never graduated. And look what happened. You're here interviewing me.

question: Come by in a few minutes. We'll do the interview.
answer: I'm worried, man.

question: Naw, we can trust him. He's a fan.
answer: But it's Rolling Stone. He looks harmless, but he does represent the magazine that trashed Eric Clapton, broke up Cream, ripped Led Zeppelin, and wrote that lame story about the Allman Brothers Band that bummed Duane out before he died. Don't forget the Rules. This little shit is the Enemy. He writes what he sees. But it would be cool to be on the cover.

question: Leave it to me. We'll get a good story.
answer: Plus our girlfriends read this magazine and - -- you know.

question: Sure. I'll take her.
answer: Me too?

question: Sure. All these people. And they all live in Phoenix.
answer: Hi Dad!! I can't talk long! I'm here in Paris. I'm staying in another Youth Hostel with no phone and no address for mail!!

question: You know. We should talk about what we don't talk about.
answer: We don't have to.

question: No, I - I went to Catholic school. I believe in guilt and... you know, if there's any to be had, I pretty much want to roll around in it.
answer: I don't believe in attachments. No boundaries. Just the music.

question: I'm just saying, it's okay to talk about it.
answer: Leslie.

question: Alright - now we're talking.
answer: Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. Lesssssslie. Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. Leslie. LESlie. Leslie...

question: Okay. I have a solution. Answer the phone. But if anyone without an English accent is on the phone... Just hang up. Or say it's the wrong room. SHOULD I COME BY LATER?
answer: YES, I'M IN TOO TRUTHFUL A MOOD!

question: MAYBE THAT'S A GOOD THING!! OKAY!
answer: GO AWAY!

question: Hello?
answer: May I speak with William please?

question: He's not here. I think he's in the bar with the Band. They just got back from the radio station. Is this Maryann with the pot?
answer: No this isn't Maryann with the pot. This is Elaine... his Mother.

question: I thought you were English.
answer: Could you please give him a message? Could you tell him to call home immediately? And could you also tell him - I know what's going on.

question: Now that you're starting to be successful, you had twenty-six years to write your first Album... and you'll have maybe four months for the second. Do you worry that the pressure of the business will get in the way of the original joy of making your music? Or
answer: Whoa! I need three more beers and my guitar before I can answer that question. Let's take a walk. For a minute I thought you were actually a real journalist... which is... you know, it's great. Shut that thing off, and I'll tell you the truth.

question: It's off.
answer: Look. I trust you. I'm going to lay this right on you. Just make us look cool.

question: I will quote you warmly and accurately.
answer: That's what I'm worried about. See - some of us have girlfriends back home. Some of us have wives. And... some of the people you meet on the road are really amazing people...

question: Ohhhh. Oh. Yeah.
answer: You know what I mean?

question: Right. Yeah.
answer: See, you're dangerous. Most people are just waiting to talk, but you listen.

question: Right. Right.
answer: So your question you asked me. I think about It every fucking night. The "business." I hate it! I grew up with these guys, okay? I can't play all that I can play, I'm past these musicians, do you understand?

question: I do.
answer: The more popular we get, the more I can't walk on them, the bigger their houses get, the more pressure... you forget, man. You forget what it was like to be real, to be a fan. You can hear it in a lot of bands who've been successful - it doesn't sound like music anymore. It sounds like... like lifestyle maintenance. I used to be able to hear the sounds of the world. Everything, to me, used to sound like music. Everything. Now I don't hear it. You know what I'm trying to say?

question: Yeah.
answer: Man, it feels good to say this stuff out loud. But what am I doing? I'm telling secrets to the one guy you don't tell secrets to.

question: No, that's okay. We'll do the interview tomorrow.
answer: This is good. So there's the "friend" and then there's the "interview guy."

question: Yeah.
answer: So tonight it's "friend".... and when we wake up tomorrow - "interview guy." We'll figure it out as we go, buddy.

question: Good evening Phoenix. From Troy, Michigan. Please welcome, Stillwater. Get in, get in!!
answer: Are you the manager of this band?

question: That, and more. Get in!
answer: You didn't even play a full set!

question: Your shoddy stage set-up almost killed our guitarist!
answer: You trashed the dressing room - you didn't play your thirty-five minutes. You didn't fulfill your contract -

question: Everybody in! Get in the bus!
answer: I'll report you to every promoter in the country! I'm gonna talk to Frank Barcelona!

question: YOU DON'T FUCK WITH MY BAND'S SAFETY!
answer: I hope you have a good lawyer.

question: I AM A LAWYER!
answer: LOCK THE GATE ON 'EM!

question: Give that to me.
answer: What will our names be?

question: What do you think of Russell?
answer: I like him.

question: You're coming to Cleveland, right?
answer: Cleveland, Ohio? Oh no no no. I gotta get my interview with Russell before Greenville. And you've got to help me. Okay? Friends... remember?

question: You should give him a break. There are real problems in the band. Off the record.
answer: What problems?

question: Okay. I got it. I think your name should be Spencer, and mine will be Jane.
answer: I can't keep up with you.

question: No one can.
answer: What's your real name?

question: Here's the thing about Russell. He's my last project. I only do this for a very few people. And I think we should do it together - he is almost great. We've got to take him there. You and me - we can do it. Deal? Because the other guys are good - but he could be great. He's my last project.
answer: What do you love about music?

question: Hey. I know. I know. I know. I know. Mom. Mom... Mom. Right now -- Topeka. Then Greenville. Then home.
answer: I guess I just miss you, and I don't understand why I've driven both my kids so far away from me. By all practical rules don't I get you for three more years?

question: I missed the last thing you said. WHAT?
answer: I MISS YOU AND I LOVE YOU!

question: Can we just skip the vibe and go straight to us laughing about this?
answer: Yeah. Okay.

question: Because I can see by your face - you want to get into this -
answer: How can you tell? I'm just one of the out-of-focus guys.

question: Here we go.
answer: Well, it speaks pretty loudly to me.

question: It's a t-shirt.
answer: I'm always gonna tell you the truth.

question: Are you doing coke again?
answer: Oh yeah. All the time.

question: Excuse me, but didn't we all get into this to avoid responsibility?
answer: Forgive me. But this is the slow-moving train of compromise that will kill us.

question: You can trust him, you can say whatever you want.
answer: I works as hard or harder than anybody on that stage. You know what I do - I connect. I get people off. I look for the guy who isn't getting off, and I make him get off. Actually, that you can print. And yet, why do I always end up feeling like I'm a joke to you? I feel nothing but love for you. We're a family.

question: Is it my turn? Because I think we should, for once, say what we really mean.
answer: Oh, this is the part where you quit -

question: Right. I'm so predictable.
answer: No I gotta tell the truth -- I want you to like me. But sometimes I feel like you collect people who love you and then very skillfully... you make them feel bad that they're not good enough for you.

question: Stick to singing, brother, 'cause you ain't gonna make it as a shrink.
answer: Deal with it! And let me just say what nobody Else wants to say to you -

question: What?
answer: Your looks have become a problem.

question: Hello Harry.
answer: You okay? You alright?

question: From here on out, I'm only interested in what's real.
answer: Thanks.

question: You know, you know all about us and I don't know shit about you. What's your... your family like? Tell me.
answer: Well, my dad died of a heart attack and my sister believes that my Mom is so intense that she might have contributed to it. Plus -

question: Okay, that's good. That's enough.
answer: It's good to talk about it. Really good.

question: If they want me, they can find me.
answer: So listen. I have to go home tomorrow. I know this is a bad time to finish our interview.

question: Hey, man, you know what? Write whatever you want. I trust you. On my better days, yes. I am "Woooooo, Russell from Stillwater!" You. Aaron. Are what it's all about. You are real. Your room is real. Your friends are real. You are more important than... than... all the silly machinery. And you know it! In eleven years it's gonna be 1984, man. Think about that! Yes. Take it! What? Okay. Good to know.
answer: We should probably head back sometime.

question: Topeka. Check it out.
answer: Please don't give him any more acid.

question: Faces. Stones. Sa-weet Baby James!! None of these people are gonna be around in twenty years! Plastic begets plastic!! Black plastic.
answer: No no. Nope. No.

question: I AM A GOLDEN GOD!!
answer: Hey Russell -

question: I AM A GOLDEN GOD!!
answer: Don't jump, okay?

question: And you can tell Rolling Stone Magazine my last words were -
answer: I think we should work on those last words.

question: Critic!!
answer: No, I'm not -

question: Okay I got it. I got it. I got it. I got it. This is better. Last words
answer: Just come on down!!

question: Okay. Thanks for saving my life. I won't hold it against you.
answer: They've been crying for you like a bunch of whimpering pussies --

question: The band is over. This is my family now.
answer: Definitely. It's all over. We'll just ride on to Greenville, listen to some great music, finish the tour, and leave those ungrateful fools behind. And then we'll come back here, where you'll live.

question: I know what you're doing... and I like it. Look at him. He's taking notes with his eyes. How do we know he's not a cop?
answer: Easy. He's your Guardian Angel.

question: Easy. He's your Guardian Angel.
answer: Which half?

question: Good question.
answer: I have a lot more. Just help me get my interview so I can go home from Greenville. I have to go home. I have to go home.

question: Hey. You saved the tour. That's good enough for now.
answer: Rolling Stone is calling me. I don't have my key interview. I don't know what to say.

question: Wait. I'll leave.
answer: Backwards?

question: I don't know. I just thought we could hang out, maybe do some stuff back home, regular stuff, get to know each other better... and then I'd see you pee. I mean, that's the way I usually do it.
answer: You're one of us. It's no big deal.

question: I'm not one of you.
answer: Oh! If you go to Cleveland, Bowie's going to be there at Swingo's, the greatest hotel in America. I'll introduce you to him, and his security guy Dennis.

question: Don't you have any regular friends?
answer: Famous people are just more interesting.

question: Well, I would be worried that they were using me. And not that anybody's using you, but -
answer: Boy, if this was the real world and some guy talked to me like that -

question: Let me finish. I'm not famous.... but you could always use me. If anything happens. And I would never use you. Even if I got famous. So you know, you always have that from me... in the real world. If you ever have to go back there, for anything.
answer: Your time has come.

question: Did he call? What are you -- stop it -- we're talking here.
answer: Pants him. Opie must die. Just relax. Take a vacation from yourself. Leave this to professionals. Hello. Hi, Ben-Fong-Torres from Rolling Stone.

question: What am I to you? Tell me right now! What. Am. I. To. You. Houdini... Houdini...
answer: GO AWAY!

question: No. I can't. You've got to help me. I have to go home.
answer: Come on man, we'll have more time there. Don't be tense!!

question: I feel... like his parents.
answer: I know.

question: I wonder how that happened.
answer: You ever notice that all our sentences begin with "I?"

question: I hadn't, no.
answer: 'Cause we should work on that.

question: Cleveland!
answer: Hi Mom. I'm in Cleveland.

question: Tell her you're a slave to the groove - you can't help it!
answer: No.

question: Hi Mom! It's Russell Hammond, I play guitar in Stillwater! It's my fault. How does it feel to be the mother of the future of rock journalism? Hello?
answer: Listen to me. Your charm does not work on me. I'm onto you. Of course you like him.

question: Yes.
answer: He worships you people and that's fine with you, as long as he helps make you rich.

question: Rich? I don't think so -
answer: Listen to me. He's a smart, good- hearted, 15 year-old kid, with infinite potential.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: If you break his spirit, harm him in any way, keep him from his chosen profession -- which is law, Something you may not value but I do -- you will meet the voice on the other end of this telephone. And it will not be pretty. Do we understand each other?

question: Yes... yes...
answer: I didn't ask for this role, but I'll play it. Now go do your best. "Be bold and mighty forces will come to your aide!" Goethe said that. It's not too late for you to be a person of substance. Get my son home safely, I'm glad we spoke.

question: We'll finish on the way to Boston. You can fly home from Boston.
answer: Hi.

question: We already have a manager. He's been with us from the beginning.
answer: Respectfully. We all have our roots. I believe in bands holding onto their roots. But those roots need to be augmented. I'm gonna tell you the truth - I may enrage some and enthrall others. I don't really give a fuck. Your manager here needs a manager. Example. If you hadn't run out on the contract in Phoenix, you could have sued over Russell's hand... but you left, negating the contract, forfeiting the deposit, and you effectively traveled a long way to pay that promoter... to electrocute you.

question: Yes, of course. Clearly. Respectfully. But on the distasteful subject of money. Just know. You're making it -- right now -- and it's all --
answer: But why should we pay you for something we can do ourselves?

question: Do you know how to keep from getting charged for the ice below the floorboards of Chicago Stadium? Do you know how to do a headlining tour, do you Claire Rothman at the L.A. Forum? Do you know Bobbi Cowan, Lisa Robinson, Jim Ladd, Frank Barcelona? This is Cleveland. Where's Kid Leo?? Do you know how you get a record not pressed but played? Do you know? I didn't invent the rainy day, man. I just own the best umbrella.
answer: Yeah, well... we'll think about what you said.

question: So it wasn't a birthday party, it was a farewell.
answer: What's that?

question: You're worried about me and Russell.
answer: Yeah. I gotta work on that.

question: You're so sweet. God -- if there was more of you in him...
answer: Don't tell me this stuff. I want to like him.

question: Did you miss your test or something?
answer: Penny -

question: Forget it. I'm flying to New York myself. I have a bunch of partial tickets. I know his ex-wife, current girlfriend's going to be there -
answer: -- I'm not sure that's a good idea.

question: What? What are you saying? What do you know? Did Russell say something?
answer: I don't know anything.

question: I know he wants me there. He gave me a cake. He wrote me that sweet poem.
answer: Wake up! Don't go to New York!

question: What are you telling me?
answer: Because you're not who you said you were! I thought you were retired!

question: You're right. I'm not who I said I was. I'm just like you. I love music, so this is my family. Some people like tractors, and they hang out with tractor people. What's the worst that could happen if I go to New York? "I get my little heart broken?"
answer: Oh no. Never you! You eat people alive!

question: I'm sorry I told you so much. You have some way of making everybody tell you all their secrets.
answer: That's a good one. Tell me too much and make it my fault.

question: Come on. You've seen what's happened. Russell and I fell in love. How much, I don't know... but this is the first time I've fallen for someone, really fallen... since Iggy, and I'm not happy about it.
answer: You slept with Iggy Pop!?

question: You'll remember me forever. I was there when you lost your virginity.
answer: So was Steely Dan! It was a crowded room.

question: You make me laugh. I think I'm gonna cry.
answer: I thought we were going to Morocco! There's no Morocco. There's never been a Morocco. There's not even a Penny Lane. I don'teven know your real name.

question: If I ever met a guy in the real world, who looked at me the way you just looked at me...
answer: When and where does the real world occur? I am really... confused here. Fuck! All these Rules And all these sayings... and nicknames...

question: You know -- you're too sweet for rock and roll.
answer: Where do you get off... where do you get "sweet?" I'm not sweet. I'm dark and mysterious and pissed-off and I could be very dangerous to all of you... I'm not sweet, and you should know that about me! I am The Enemy.

question: You're not any of those things and that's what I love about you.
answer: You fall in love to keep from falling in love.

question: I don't want to go home!
answer: Well, I have to go home. And you never helped me.

question: Yes I did.
answer: That disc-jockey in Arizona got a better interview than me... and he was asleep.

question: Look. You should be happy for me. You don't know what he says to me in private. Maybe it is love. As much as it can be with someone who --
answer: -- sold you to Humble Pie for fifty dollars and a case of beer? I was there!

question: Ah ha! There you are, ya little fucker. Come on --
answer: I have some good news.

question: -- I'll piss to that. Follow me. Dennis Hope took me aside, and wants to manage Me solo. Says to lose the band by February. Should I do it? I have no perspective anymore.
answer: I do.

question: Oh - get this - somebody told Penny Lane I sold her for beer. The network of these chicks! Like I would do that. It's Jeff who told her, right? Not you, right? None of these guys can just calm down and be a fuckin adult. Now she's here, freaking out. Leslie can smell it.
answer: Wait. I've got something to tell - You guys -- you guys -- You're gonna be on the cover of Rolling Stone.

question: Oh -- wonderful. Front desk? Please send a doctor. Room... what room? 703. 702. Both rooms, either room. This is Mr. Rugburn, Yes. My wife's had an accident with some quaaludes. Yes - I'll do that. "In the unlikely event of a water landing... "
answer: "... you will be required to wear a safety vest."

question: Keep going.
answer: "Please place all stowable luggage in the overhead compartments... out in the seat in front of you."

question: "Seat and tray tables."
answer: "And seat-backs and tray-tables should be in their full and upright and locked positions... "

question: Well. Now that I have your attention. And you may not remember this later, I just want to make it clear that... Hey! I know you've heard this before. And I have never said this to anybody, not really - well, nobody who didn't legally have to say it back to me, but - I love you. And I have a hard time sharing you with all of rock and roll because I - why am I nervous? - You'll never remember this - HEY! - I love you, and I'm about to boldly go where... Many men have gone before...
answer: Your wife will be okay for now -

question: Thank you Doctor.
answer: However, she says you're her brother.

question: She's a little confused.
answer: Nice champagne.

question: I don't have a driver's license. With me.
answer: Tomorrow's my wedding anniversary. I'd prefer to take care of this without facing the dawn at the police station. So if you can find a way to get this girl - your wife - back home to her parents, I'd let you pay me anything you can afford. Because you don't appear to be related to the famous Rugburns of Rhode Island.

question: Happy Anniversary.
answer: She won't be good company, but keep her awake for another four hours.

question: When I was 14, my Mom and her boyfriend took me to a Rolling Stones concert - and I freaked out and I rushed up to the front of the stage and then a thousand people had the same idea at the same time and I was getting crushed. And I couldn't breathe and that thought flashed through me - almost like a car accident - I thought I might die. And it was in the middle of "Midnight Rambler" and Keith Richards saw me. And he came over, and came to the front of the stage, and he pulled me out. And they took me backstage and they gave me coke with ice and a - and a lemon. And I never went home.
answer: What about your Mom?

question: She always said - "Marry Up." Marry someone grand. That's why she named me Lady.
answer: She named you Lady?

question: Lady Goodman.
answer: No.

question: You never really get used to it, either.
answer: Well -- this -- this just explains everything.

question: See you back there.
answer: Hey Lady!

question: "Pretty pretty pretty pretty Peggy Sue... "
answer: We shouldn't be here.

question: Doris, we miss you!
answer: "Electrical storm?"

question: Oh baby.
answer: We can't run this piece.

question: You obviously saw more than you wrote about. After eight days on the road with these guys.
answer: And where are you in this piece? What did you want to write? Because this reads like what they wanted you to write.

question: What happened to your highly-touted think piece on limitations of a middle- level Band in the face of success?
answer: We can push up Chet's Who cover -

question: Yes. It took it in grade school.
answer: Aw, man. You made friends with them! See, friendship is the booze they feed you. They want you to get drunk on feeling like you belong.

question: Well, it was fun.
answer: They make you feel cool. And hey. I met you. You are not "cool."

question: I know. Even when I though I was, I knew I wasn't.
answer: That's because we are uncool! And while women will always be a problem for guys like us, most of the great art in the world is about that very problem. Good-looking people have no spine! Their art never lasts! They get the girls, but we're smarter.

question: I can really see that now.
answer: Yeah, great art is about conflict and pain and guilt and longing and love disguised as sex, and sex disguised as love... and let's face it, you got a big head start.

question: I'm glad you were home.
answer: I'm always home! I'm uncool!

question: Me too!
answer: The only true currency in this bankrupt world if what we share with someone else when we're uncool.

question: I feel better
answer: Be honest and unmerciful. You're doing great. Call me later is you want. I'm always up.

question: Look. Let's just piece together our information... because the fact-checker asked us all about different parts of the story. It. All. He's using it all.
answer: So what?

question: So what? We come off like amateurs... some average band... trying to come to grips, jealous and fighting and breaking up - we're buffoons!
answer: Maybe we just don't see ourselves the way we really are.

question: He was supposed to be our friend.
answer: I told him to write what he wanted. Oh my God.

question: They used him to fuck us.
answer: I didn't say "Golden God." Or did I?

question: I feel bad.
answer: Well, at least you feel. That puts you in a higher class of asshole.

question: What did I do?
answer: Well - you can do what the big boys do. Nothing.

question: Yeah.
answer: You believe these new girls? None of 'em take birth control, and they eat all the steak.

question: Is Penny okay?
answer: The Quaalude Incident. Yeah, it wasn't pretty. She could have died. I always warned her about letting too many guys fall in love with her. I guess I was wrong. On of 'em saved her life.

question: Well, it's finally over with Leslie. I'm going to call her.
answer: Let her retire. You want to lock her up in a house in Michigan? Please. Write her a song someday. She deserves it. Something about that girl brought out the best in a lot of... ... pretty average people. She deserves it...

question: William? You guys, I'll deadhead back later. I think I'm needed. You look awful, but that's great. You're living your life! You're finally free of... her.
answer: Yeah.

question: Hey. I'll take off work. Let's have an adventure together. You and me, finally. Anywhere you want to go. Anywhere in the world. This is not my idea of a good time.
answer: Just get me to my bed.
